page.title: 15LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: The name{Eccleston}originally meant {Churchtown}or{Churchfarm.}Until the earlier part of this century{Eccleston was mainly{country. There was some industry,including a few mines and quarries.Several farms had potteries attached to them. There was a{clay pipe factory}and near{Lane Ends}and{Portico}there were about fifteen{watch movement makers. In{1770}the small colliery at{ {Gillars Green}was recorded as selling coal for{1p per hundredweight.}The mineworkers earned{92p per week.} {William Shakespeare}is thought to have acted in an old tithe barn in{ {Burrows Lane.}This is linked to the fact that Elizabethan players were said to have performed at{Knowsley {Hall.} In{1590}a playhouse was said to have been on{Eccleston waste}near{Prescot.}
